pros: Flexible working, Work from home. Open door policy. Everyone works together as a team. Relaxed atmosphere.
cons: Poor IT Salary is not in line with the rising cost of living.

pros: Great Team environment Opportunity for Promotion Supportive Varied workload
cons: Can be challenging but worth it

pros: I suppose it’s rewarding to work with vulnerable people? There are other companies where you can do that though, and not get treated like a dog turd and paid peanuts.
cons:
I will simply copy and paste what someone else has put as its bang on the money.

“Bullying management, poor pay, massive staff turn over. Management have no people skills whatsoever and rule by fear”

Added to that - they constantly put staff in danger by poor management of risk, and don’t really care that much about the service users, just about funding. They talk a good game but don’t realise how bad they really are. Now I’ve moved on and work for somewhere that actually cares, I understand just how bad they are.

pros: No day was ever the same, some lovely colleagues and important work with social value
cons: No training, no investment in staff retention, constant additions to workload without consideration for capacity to complete tasks, IT equipment/systems out of date, expected to work hard and long hours but not looked after once it takes a toll on mental health, cliquey, limited routes for progression, blame culture

review_title: Worst job i have ever had
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Buxton, East Midlands, England
pros: Really enjoy working with the customers and staff are friendly enough.
cons:
The senior management are outrageous, they really don't have a clue.  Very unprofessional and really rude to customers and staff.
The accommodation is of real poor quality.  The service is funded by housing benefit, what a waste of hard earned tax payers money.  Why is there no quality checks made by the funders?  At least monthly?
Health and safety is a joke.  Managers are ineffective it's like hey are scared to actually mange. Would rather have a laugh, like they are hanging with their mates.
The focus is on voids and money, nothing else.

review_title: Rule driven with no concern for staff or residents
job_title: Housing Support Bank Staff in Liverpool, England
pros: working with nice people in the main both staff and clients except for management who were under tremendous pressure and often  promoted above their abilities
cons: Local management I have never in all my working years met a team of managers so bullied and scared for their jobs not a healthy place to work

pros: Management listen to their staff and take on board what is said to look st changes that will make a better organisation and service delivery. All staff are approachable and will signpost you to the relevant person if they are unable to help. Pay package is excellent.
cons: As the government squeezes local authority budgets even tighter, there is no guarantee of continuity with homeless provision

job_title: Housing Officer in Hockley, West Midlands, England
pros: I enjoyed working with some of the customers and a couple of colleagues . Close to city centre for court attendances
cons: Managers that have little knowledge on housing law, very poor rate of pay , no room for staff to grow. Very little training for front line staff . Too many managers.  Very little concern for staffs health and safety . No staff incentives .

review_title: Best company I have worked for, there for 12 years before being made redundant. Would work for them again
pros: Values, ethos, caring organisation. They supper clients into work through their Social Enterprise
cons: Nature of work mean services are tendered every few years so no job security

pros: Given the current climate, Adullam is doing it's best to sustain each employee.
cons: Funding is constantly being stopped through the government and Adullam is left with no alternative but to close schemes

pros: The  best part of the job is working with the tenants  and some of my colleagues
cons: Lack of management support and leadership.  Management telling staff that they must share their food with each other.  There are too may management layers.  Lack of training, poor salary, there isn't any opportunities for career progression
